ArticleInfo.ArticleTitle: Nanostars on a fiber facet with near field enhancement for surface-enhanced Raman scattering detection

Abstract.Heading: Abstract
Abstract.Para: A 4-pointed gold nanostar is proposed to form the array on a fiber facet to achieve a greatly enhanced near field intensity for Surface-Enhanced Raman Scattering (SERS) detection. The proposed gold nanostar array has a Surface Plasmon Resonance (SPR) peaked at a wavelength of ∼650 nm with up to 45 times electric field intensity enhancement compared with the state-of-the-art nanorod design. It has a wideband SPR field enhancement spanned from 600 to 720 nm, which covers the wavelengths for both the excitation light (632.8 nm) and the Raman signal of the analytes (675–706 nm); With symmetrical structure it forms four hot spots in every unit cell and can detect best for light polarized horizontal or perpendicular to the waist of the nanostars. It also could be altered to tune the SPR and allows the fiber sensor to resonate at different wavelengths, as demonstrated by an example at 533 nm. All the above features make the gold nanostar-based compact and portable fiber sensor an attractive solution for SERS detection.

Section1.Heading: Introduction
Section1.Para: Surface-Enhanced Raman Scattering (SERS) has emerged as a very promising spectroscopy method. A variety of metal plasmonic nano-architectures can improve the capabilities of SERS towards single molecule detection limits and towards spatial resolution of few nanometers. They include nanosphere dimers, nanocubes, nanotriangular arrays, nano-pyramid shells, nanorods, nanowires, nanotips, and some unconventional nano-architectures as reviewed in [1]. These metal nano-architectures are normally fabricated on the bulk substrate. Recently, Capasso and co-workers have shown that optical antenna arrays can be fabricated on an optical fiber and can be utilized for in situ SERS detection [2]. Without bulky lens these nano-antennas on the fiber facet significantly simplify the SERS spectroscopy design with reduced complexity, size and cost, and make home use spectroscopy for selected disease diagnosis possible.

Fabrication of the metal nanostructures on the fiber facet is very challenging. Novel processes such as the transfer method [3], the nanoimprinting [4], the focused ion beam [5] and the E-beam directly patterned method [6] have been tried. The challenge of designing the nano-optical antenna comes from the different physical properties and scaling behavior compared with the traditional ones, most of which arise from metals that are not perfect conductors and have a Surface Plasmon Resonance (SPR). This forces us to enter the new area of plasmons to explain the antenna mechanism. The study of the nano-antenna on the fiber facet is even more challenging and there is no in-depth analysis. The important issues such as design tools, parameter study, and fiber index influence need to be studied. In this paper, we will use Lumerical FDTD solutions as a design tool to study these issues [7]. We consider the case that the fiber is an electrically large structure compared with the nanostructures in wavelengths of interest. For example, gold nanorods (length: 65 nm, width: 50 nm, and height: 40 nm) are distributed very intensively (spacing: 25 nm and 100 nm) on the fiber facet to achieve the SPR over 600–720 nm. There are ∼694×415 units used to cover the fiber core with a diameter of 62.5 μm in [2]. Thus, in this case gold nanocells are simply assumed as periodic structures and only one unit cell will be designed using periodic boundary conditions.

The gold nanocells are designed with an aim to achieve the large optical near field enhancement, and hence the SERS enhancement. This is because we know that the dominant contribution to SERS enhancement is due to electromagnetic enhancement (the other contribution is chemical enhancement). Under the normal condition, the Raman enhancement factor can be approximated to the incident electric field intensity with the power of four, |E(λ inc)|4, where λ inc is the incident wavelength [8]. With this aim, the hot spots are usually preferable at the vicinity of the nanocells with tremendously enhanced local optical field, hence leading to an enormous enhancement in their SERS. The nanostructure parameters such as size, shape, morphology, arrangement, and local environment can be optimized to facilitate such hot spots. In this paper, a 4-pointed gold nanostar shape is proposed to form the array and produce the hot spots on a fiber facet to achieve the greatly enhanced near field intensity and then the SERS. It is designed to achieve the wideband SPR field enhancement spanned from 600 to 720 nm, which covers the wavelengths for both the excitation light (632.8 nm) and the Raman signal of the analytes (675–706 nm). With the excitation wavelength of 632.8 nm we conveniently call it the 633 nm design in this paper. Also, the tunability is demonstrated with the named 533 nm design for an excitation wavelength of 532.8 nm.

In this paper, the geometry of the gold nanostars on the fiber facet is detailed in Sect. 2. In Sect. 3, the unit cell is designed to achieve the great near field intensity over 600–720 nm by comparing the state-of-art nanorod design. The great near field enhancement, wideband enhancement, and two best detection directions, these three advantages will be demonstrated. The fourth advantage of the tunability is demonstrated in Sect. 4 with a design at 533 nm. Section 5 summarizes the results.

Section1.Heading: Geometry of the gold nanostars on the fiber facet
Section1.Para:
Figure 1 shows the geometry of the gold nanostar unit cells on the fiber facet. The zoom in view shows 3×3 unit cells for better illustration. The denoted geometry dimensions include the star width a, star waist width d, star cell height h, and star spacing g. The cells are distributed uniformly and intensively on the fiber facet. To compare with the state-of-the-art reference gold nanorod design, here we use the same fiber type of GIF625 [2]. As illustrated in Fig. 1, the fiber has a core diameter of 62.5 μm and cladding diameter of 125 μm. Usually the nano-patterns are fabricated and extended to the cladding area to ensure that the nanocells can cover the core area without any discontinuities, such as bead [6]. As shown in Fig. 1, more than 600×600 nano-cells are distributed to cover the fiber core area. Considering the wavelengths of interest the fiber is an electrically large structure for the nano-cells. Here, we make the reasonable assumption that the unit cells are periodically distributed on the fiber substrate and the initial design is simplified to correspond to a unit cell. It is also noted that the fiber GIF625 is a gradient index fiber type and the index profile is considered from its datasheet as provided by ThorLabs [9]. Its index ranges from 1.4575 to 1.4875. As simulated the gradient index has no big influence on the electric field intensity and thus we use a value of 1.4875 at the fiber core center.
Fig. 1
Gold nanostars on a fiber facet with an illustration of 3×3 unit cells: the image plane is at 1 nm above the top of the nanostar surface; a=52 nm, g=45 nm, h=40 nm, and d=20 nm for the 633 nm design and d=40 nm for the 533 nm design

The design is simulated in Lumerical FDTD solutions. The structure are programmed using script so that its shape can be easily changed by only altering the geometry variables. The simple plane wave with one polarization direction is first used to excite the nanocells over a certain wavelength range. A finer mesh is applied in the nanostar region with dx, dy and dz set as 0.5 nm, thereby improving the accuracy and speed of the simulation. The image plane is reasonably set at 1 nm above the top of the gold nanostar surface [10] for the near field detection purpose. The electromagnetic fields are solved using FDTD numerical methods. The electric field intensity |E|2 at the image plane is finally plotted at different wavelengths. The gold nanostar dimension is varied until the maximum |E|2 can be obtained at the image plane for the resonant wavelength. In simulation it is found that the resonance can be tuned by altering the shape parameters. For example, the larger a can make structure resonant at the larger wavelengths as expected. The increased d shifts the resonance to smaller wavelengths. Tuning the g to a larger value in a certain range enhances the maximum electric field intensity at the resonant wavelength. This knowledge helps us to obtain an optimum design as well as to analyze the resonance shift due to the deformation in actual fabrication.

Section1.Heading: Performance at 633 nm
Section1.Para:
With the optimized gold nanostar dimensions of a=52 nm, d=20 nm, h=40 nm, and g=45 nm, a good result is achieved for the 633 nm design. For comparison, the referenced nanorod in [2] is simulated with the exact data and setting from the paper. Figure 2 shows the maximum value of the |E|2 at the image plane over wavelengths. Figure 4 shows the electric field intensity plots of a unit cell at the image plane with a color bar maximum of 200 (V/m)2. It is noted that the incident electric field E in is 1 V/m. The plane wave polarization directions are also denoted by the vertical or the horizontal arrows.
Fig. 2
Max|E|2 at the image plane with incident electric field of 1 V/m for the 633 nm nanostar and nanorod

As expected, the nanorod shows the crescent shaped hot spots areas with great electric field enhancement occurring at the nanorod gaps for all wavelengths of interest, which covers both the excitation light (632.8 nm) and the Raman signal of the analytes (675–706 nm). It is also found that the nanorod array is sensitive to the excited light polarization. The Max|E|2 at the image plane is 148–382 (V/m)2 over 600–720 nm as shown in Fig. 2. When the E in polarization direction is rotated by 90 degree, the Max|E|2 is decreased to 32–70 (V/m)2 over 600–720 nm. This confirms the experimental results as claimed in [2]: “We did not detect any SPR with the white light polarized perpendicular to the long axis of the antennas.”

Compared with the reference gold nanorod design, the gold nanostar achieves great electric field enhancement. As shown in Fig. 2 the Max|E|2 at the image plane is 1769–12111 (V/m)2 over 600–720 nm. It has a SPR peaked at ∼650 nm with 45 times electric field intensity enhancement compared with that of the nanorod design. The wideband SPR field enhancement from 600 to 720 nm is also demonstrated. From the electric field intensity plots at the image plane in Fig. 4, the advantage of this gold nanostar is obvious with greatly enhanced hot spots area and intensity, especially at the peak resonance wavelength of 650 nm. It is also noted that due to the symmetrical structure the nanostar can detect best for light polarized horizontal or perpendicular to its waist. This shows the great advantage over the nanorod design and leads to better detection. In addition, having four hot spots in every nanostar cell provides a larger detection volume compared with the conventional dimmer configuration with two hot spots per unit cell, such as bowtie etc. This property makes the hot spots more uniformly distributed and increases the detection possibilities.

Section1.Heading: Tunability to 533 nm
Section1.Para:
The proposed gold nanostar could be altered to tune the SPR and allow the fiber sensor to resonate at different excitation wavelengths. Compared with the 633 nm design, we only increase the star waist width d from 20 to 40 nm to effectively tune the resonance to 533 nm. Figure 3 shows that the Max|E|2 is 13–1894 (V/m)2 over 500–620 nm. Figure 5 shows the electric field intensity plots of a unit cell at the image plane with a color bar maximum of 200 (V/m)2. It is noted that E in is 1 V/m. The plane wave polarization directions are also denoted by the vertical or the horizontal arrows. As expected, the 533 nm nanostar has the same characteristics of the 633 nm design as great electric field enhancement, wideband enhancement, two best detection directions, and four hot spots in every unit cell for better detection.

We also simulate the fiber index effect on the electric field intensity at the image plane. The index value of 1.54 is used to correspond to the silica fiber core case or crystal quartz substrate case. As shown in Fig. 3, the electric field intensity difference is insignificant for 1.485 and 1.54 cases. The same conclusion is drawn for the 633 nm design. This simulation also validates our design methodology that only uses the index value at the fiber core center to reduce the simulation complexity.

Section1.Heading: Conclusions
Section1.Para: The 4-pointed gold nanostar array was proposed on a fiber facet for SERS detection. Its wideband great electric field enhancement property over 600–720 nm was demonstrated with 45 times electric field intensity enhancement at 650 nm when compared with the state-of-art gold nanorod design. It provides four hot spots in every unit cell in the image plane and leads to a larger hot spot volume for better detection. With symmetrical structure, it demonstrates best responsivity to the light polarized horizontally or perpendicularly to the waist of the nanostars. Its tunability to resonate to other wavelengths was also demonstrated by a 533 nm design example. With these good properties, the gold nanostar-based compact and portable fiber sensor shows the potentials to be an attractive solution for SERS detection. With the development of the nanofabrication technologies on the fiber facet [3–6], the fabrication of the proposed nanostar array is becoming possible. In addition, the more challenging structures, such as the non-uniform nanocells using the transformation optics metamaterials concept and the 3D multilayered geometry [11], can be tried to further improve this type of fiber sensor for SERS detection, e.g., a metal superlens can be added on the top of the nano-antenna array to further translate the hot spots to increase the detection volume [10].
